titlestmt.sponsor: This collection-level EAD record is a product of the Philadelphia Area Consortium of Special Collections Libraries (PACSCL) Consortial Survey Initiative, which was funded by the Andrew W. Mellon Foundation.

profiledesc.creation: Machine-readable finding aid generated in EAD from data in the PACSCL Consortial Survey Database on 12/21/2012. Modified by Dot Porter in 2017.

bioghist.p: Virginia Orr Maes (1920-1986) was a marine malacologist who worked at the Academy of Natural Sciences of Philadelphia. She attended Wellesley College from 1938 to 1940. Her interest in malacology was sparked by a course in the subject given in the 1950s by John Dyas Parker, who was an assistant to Henry Pilsbry. Maes volunteered at the Academy and later became a Scientific Assistant in the Department of Mollusks (later called the Department of Malacology). She worked with Pilsbry, then with R. Tucker Abbott. Upon her marriage to Robert Maes, she gave up her salary and became a research associate. In 1970, she was appointed Research Fellow, the position she held until her death in 1986.

scopecontent.p: This is a collection of the papers of Virginia Orr Maes. Materials in the collection include: incoming and outgoing correspondence; species notebooks which include bibliographic references, often with photographs, illustrations and extracts from the citation pasted in; notes, sketches and photographs of specimens; notes, tables of dimensions and ratios, illustrations, and manuscripts of articles (1959-1965) often accompanied by a printed version; computer printout of Maes specimens in the collections of the Academy of Natural Sciences; figures, plates, negatives, and a reprint of Littoral Marine Mollusks of Cocos-Keeling Islands (1967) and a species location file for specimens she collected in the Cocos; and photos and journals from a 1950-1951 trip to Africa. The collection also includes obituaries of Maes, letters of condolence to her husband, correspondence related to the Virginia Orr Maes Memorial Fund; and several personal photos.

accessrestrict.p: The collection is open for research.

otherfindaid.p: An inventory is available in the repository.
